snippet: A Bedouin man has struggled with uncertainty over whether joining a revolt was life’s proudest moment or its ruin — or both.
abstract: Abu Zeid's evolution from carefree tour guide to Syrian revolutionary offers a rare glimpse of a life transformed by an uprising that has jolted thousands from their daily routines; he and several friends took up arms after security officers shot demonstrators in Tadmur; now, alternately passionate and confused, he has only the dimmest idea of an endgame and has taken refuge in Lebanon.

byline.contributor: An employee of The New York Times contributed reporting from Syria, and another employee of The Times from a neighboring country.

lead_paragraph: A Bedouin man has struggled with uncertainty over whether joining a revolt was life’s proudest moment or its ruin — or both.
